long_desc.thetext: With the current layout managers, that are provided by SWT, some things are really unhandy to code. Unhandy in the sense of generating bloated code. The situation intensifies as there is no good GUI builder available for Eclipse Europe. On the other side, there is currently a top 25 enhancement request at Sun to include MigLayout (the Swing part only) to JDK 7. As MigLayout (www.miglayout.com) also supports SWT it would be nice to have it in SWT as well. MigLayout is under the BSD license. If you don't know it, then please give it a try, or look at a little example (picture + code) I set up on my page (http://www.medicalgenomics.org/miglayout_sample). As you'll see, the code is good readable and comparatively short.

There is even a file called called IDEUtil that is made for IDE interaction in the distribution. It can be used to parse and output the constraints needed, both as strings and chainable API calls. This should make IDE integration a snap.

I'm using MigLayout in two production projects. I'd love it if I didn't have to explain what it was and why I'm using it any more. I'm willing to help with test/coding/documentation if help is needed.

+1
I usually lean against integration of third-party stuff into SWT. However, in this particular case, I would be in favor of it. MiGLayout is absolutely tremendous, and could even be the basis for a far more powerful VE plugin.

+1 BUT, wouldn't it be preferable to replace text-based configuration with a class? Even in Kai's simple example you'd need to remember format and keywords for:
"[right]10[left, grow]" "growx, wrap" "width 100!, split" "gapleft 10, wrap"
Not to mention that some of that is rather cryptic (e.g. what does exclamation mark means? Negation? Fixed size? If so, what kind of size it is without it?). I know I can read documentation, I'm just trying to tell that it's not obvious.
To make it more compact it could be a chained operation, e.g.
label.setLayoutData(new MIGLayoutData().setLeftGap(10).setWrap());
This way compiler can check at least for syntax validity of such configuration statement (and we all like when we know about errors sooner than later, don't we? :))

Max,
Thank you for your support.
Luckily I have already added exactly that type of API you are looking for. Look in the Swing demo at the last two examples.
You can write code that looks like:
new MigLayout(new LC().fill().wrap().width("200"));
Same type of API works for column/row and component constraints.
Cheers, Mikael

I'm not sure where an appropriate place for such a layout would be. The only place currently dealing with multi widget toolkit support is UFaceKit [1] which supports various widget technologies from SWT over Swing to QT(Jambi) and we are already using Mig-Layout in our internal implementations.

Hello Tom,
Just to be clear, MigLayout supports both Swing and SWT (and JavaFX) but this is through different code bases. There is a separate .jar for the different widget frameworks. So, I think that you should maybe only include the SWT part. About 90% of the code if common for all ports of course, but that shouldn't mean that the SWT version is "polluted" by Swing and JavaFX and vice versa.
When it comes to licensing I am very flexible and can release MigLayout under any license you want. I am very pragmatic and just want this layout manager to be used as much as possible.
Porting it to Qt sounds very interesting. Let me now if you need something from me to make this easier.
Cheers, Mikael

Hi Mikael,
Do I get this right you don't have a common base but when fixing a problem in the common stuff you fix it twice (once in the SWT-Code base and once in the Swing-Code base).
Could you please provide me with a link to your source-code-repository to check out the code and take a look.

Tom,
I don't have to fix it twice furtunately. Internally I have all sources (except the JavaFX port which is hosted by Dean Iverson) in one repo. But the SWT and Swing specific code is held in different packages. The common package, which is the layout engine (the 90%), is totally widget platform independent. So if you want a pure SWT version is very easy to get.
The two packages you want is:
net.miginfocom.layout.* (no widget references, just two proxy interfaces) net.miginfocom.swt.* (three SWT impl. classes)
I have the SVN repo on an internal server ATM. Since I guess you'll be hosting this in some other repo would it be OK if you just got the source from the source.jar?
If you are going to add MigLayout I guess we should discuss how to formalize the process for when I fix a bug in it so that you can get that change in a good and orderly way.
Cheers, Mikael
